stem: The nurse is performing a physical assessment of a client's abdomen. Place the assessment techniques in the correct order of performance.

options.text: Deep palpation to assess organ borders.
Auscultation for bowel sounds in all four quadrants.
Percussion to assess for gas, fluid, or organ size.
Light palpation for tenderness or masses.
Inspection of the skin, contour, and symmetry.

rationale.correct: The correct order for abdominal assessment is inspection, auscultation, percussion, and palpation (IAPP). (1) Inspection provides a baseline visual assessment of the skin, contour, and symmetry. (2) Auscultation is performed before palpation or percussion because these maneuvers can stimulate bowel sounds, leading to inaccurate findings. (3) Percussion helps to assess the size and density of abdominal organs, as well as the presence of fluid or gas. (4) Light palpation is performed to identify areas of tenderness or superficial masses. (5) Deep palpation is used to assess the size and location of deeper organs and to detect deeper masses.
rationale.incorrect: Palpating or percussing before auscultating can artificially increase bowel sounds, leading to inaccurate assessment. Performing deep palpation before light palpation can cause unnecessary discomfort and guarding, making it difficult to assess for superficial tenderness or masses.
clinicalPearls: Always warm your hands before palpating the abdomen to minimize muscle guarding.
If the client reports pain, assess that area last.

Normal bowel sounds are high-pitched, gurgling sounds occurring irregularly, ranging from 5 to 30 per minute. Absence of bowel sounds requires listening for 5 minutes in each quadrant before documenting as absent.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember I-A-P-P for Abdomen. (Listen second instead of last).

reviewUnits.heading: Abdominal Examination and Interpretation
reviewUnits.body: Nurses assess for 'Rebound Tenderness' (sign of peritonitis) and monitor for signs of obstruction (high-pitched tinkling sounds vs absent sounds).

sbar.situation: The nurse is performing a routine abdominal assessment on a client.
sbar.background: The client has a history of occasional constipation but no other significant gastrointestinal issues. The client denies any abdominal pain at this time.
sbar.assessment: The nurse is systematically assessing the abdomen using inspection, auscultation, percussion, and palpation to identify any abnormalities.
sbar.recommendation: Continue to monitor the client's bowel habits and report any significant changes or new findings to the healthcare provider. Educate the client on strategies to prevent constipation, such as increasing fiber and fluid intake.
